titleStmt.title: The Taunton maids delight, or, Hey for the honest woosted-comber. In Taunton town a maid doth dwell, who loves a woosted-comber very well, in the praise of him she doth declare, no other tradesman can with him compare. All sweethe [sic] arts that doth come she does refuse, only a woosted-comber she doth chuse, to him she wisheth good prosperity, for 'tis a comber must her husband be. The tune is, I have a good old mother at home, &c. / T.L.
titleStmt.author: Lanfiere, Thomas.

titleStmt.title: The Taunton maids delight, or, Hey for the honest woosted-comber. In Taunton town a maid doth dwell, who loves a woosted-comber very well, in the praise of him she doth declare, no other tradesman can with him compare. The tune is, I have a good old mother at home, &c. / T.L.
titleStmt.author: Lanfiere, Thomas.

publicationStmt.publisher: Printed for P[hilip]. Brooksby at the golden Ball in VVest- Smithfield,

notesStmt.note: Verse: "You pretty maids where e're you are ..."
Date, place of publication and publisher's name from Wing.
Reproduction of original in the Harvard University, Houghton Library.
